questions.text: Imminent gangrene in peripheral vascular disease (PVD) is associated with an ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) of less than:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ABPI - ankle-brachial pressure index is the ratio of the systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. It is interpreted as the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery serving as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator. Patients with an ABPI of <0.50 are twice as likely to deteriorate as patients with an ABPI of >0.50, and a deteriorating ABI is predictive of future limb loss. Interpretation of various measurements of ABPI is as follows:

  • ≥0.9 - normal (Option A ruled out)
  • 7-0.9 - mild arterial disease (claudication may be absent or mild) (Option B ruled out)
  • ~0.5 - suggests critical ischemia / rest pain may occur (Option C ruled out)
  • <0.3 - indicates severe ischemia / impending tissue necrosis (imminent gangrene)

It should be noted that low ABPI reflects very poor distal perfusion. When ABPI drops below about 0.3 the perfusion is insufficient to sustain tissue and necrosis/gangrene is imminent.

Key takeaways:

ABPI <0.5 → rest pain; <0.3 → imminent necrosis/gangrene.

questions.text: Which of these is not a contraindication to breast-conserving therapy (BCT)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breast-conserving therapy (lumpectomy + whole-breast radiation) is appropriate when the tumour can be completely excised with acceptable cosmesis. It is aimed at removing the tumour along with a 1-cm margin of normal breast tissue.

Classic contraindications include:

  • Prior chest/breast irradiation (would preclude re-irradiation).
  • Diffuse/multicentric tumours not amenable to single excision.
  • Persistently positive margins that cannot be re-excised.
  • Severe connective tissue diseases (e.g., scleroderma) - because radiotherapy causes exaggerated soft-tissue injury.

Conversely, a tumour limited to one quadrant is an indication for BCT (not a contraindication). The tumour being confined to one quadrant generally allows adequate resection with good cosmesis.

Explanation of other options:

Prior chest radiation (Option A): contraindication (cannot safely give required adjuvant breast irradiation).

Positive margins after resection (Option B): if margins cannot be cleared with re-excision, BCT is contraindicated.

Scleroderma (Option C): relative/absolute contraindication due to radiosensitivity and risk of severe radiation-induced injury.

Key takeaways:

BCT = lumpectomy + radiotherapy; suitability depends on tumour location/size, prior radiation status, connective tissue disease, and ability to achieve clear margins.

Explanation:

Z-plasty is a classic local transposition/advancement technique (three-limb Z formation) used primarily to lengthen a contracted linear scar, change scar direction to fall along skin lines, and break up straight-line scars. The central limb is aligned with the scar and two triangular flaps are transposed; the effect is a lengthening of the central limb and reorientation of the scar. Although it involves local transposition of triangular flaps (Option D ruled out), its primary purpose in exam terms is scar lengthening/releasing contracture (answer A).

Explanation of other options:

Technique of flap creation (Option B): partly true (Z-plasty makes local triangular flaps) but the classical definition emphasizes lengthening/reorientation rather than simply "flap creation."

Zig-zag suture (Option C): not accurate; Z-plasty is a flap design, not merely suture pattern.

Local transposition flap (Option D): technically, Z-plasty is a form of local transposition, but the exam wording expects the specific goal: scar lengthening.

questions.text: A female presents with bleeding per rectum. A mass is felt 6 cm from anal verge. The tumour shows intra-mucosal carcinoma. What is the stage of the cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intra-mucosal carcinoma = carcinoma limited to the mucosa (no invasion through muscularis mucosae into submucosa) → this corresponds to carcinoma in situ, which maps to stage 0.

questions.text: Recurrent urinary stones occur in all of these except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Common metabolic risk factors for recurrent renal/ureteric calculi include hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hyperuricosuria - these promote stone formation. Citrate binds calcium and inhibits stone nucleation and growth; therefore low citrate (hypocitraturia) predisposes to stones, while high citrate (hypercitraturia) is protective. Thus hypercitraturia is not a cause of recurrent stones →it reduces stone risk.

Explanation of other options:

Hyperoxaluria (Option A): increases calcium-oxalate precipitation.

Hyperuricosuria (Option B): uric acid can nucleate calcium stones or form uric acid stones.

Hypercalciuria (Option C): most common metabolic abnormality in recurrent stone formers.

choices.text: A common cause of tension pneumothorax is positive pressure ventilation (PPV)
Thoracic spine injury can cause pneumothorax
Breath sounds are absent on the affected side
Simple pneumothorax cannot convert into a tension pneumothorax

questions.text: All the following are true regarding tension pneumothorax except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space and cannot escape → intrapleural pressure rises; mediastinal shift and cardiovascular compromise follow. A recognized precipitant is positive-pressure ventilation (PPV) in a patient with existing alveolar/pleural injury..

Thoracic spine/penetrating chest injury can cause pneumothorax.

Absent breath sounds on the affected side are a classic sign (others include hyperresonance, distended neck veins, hypotension).

Crucially: a simple pneumothorax can progress to a tension pneumothorax (for example if a valve mechanism develops or further air entry occurs under positive pressure). So, the statement "simple pneumothorax cannot convert" is incorrect


Key takeaways:

In trauma/ventilated patients always watch for conversion of simple pneumothorax to tension. Immediate decompression (needle thoracostomy/thoracostomy) is required in unstable patients.

questions.text: Most common pituitary tumour in clinical practice is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among pituitary adenomas that present clinically, prolactin-secreting (prolactinomas) are the most common functioning tumours. Functioning adenomas (especially prolactinomas) produce hormonal syndromes that bring patients to clinical attention earlier.

Non-functioning adenomas are also common (often present as macroadenomas with mass effect), but prolactinomas are the most common single subtype encountered in clinical practice.

Explanation of other options:

GH producing adenomas (Option A): causes acromegaly; are less common than prolactinomas.

ACTH adenomas (Option B): causes Cushing's disease and are less common.

Non-functional adenomas (Option D): are common (often diagnosed by mass effect), but among clinical presenting tumours with endocrine features, functioning adenomas (especially prolactinomas) are the most common single type.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in stage T4b breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TNM definitions: T4b = tumour of any size with ulceration and/or ipsilateral macroscopic satellite nodules and/or edema (including peau d'orange) of the skin that does not meet criteria for inflammatory carcinoma.

T4d = inflammatory carcinoma - defined clinically as diffuse erythema and edema involving ≥1/3 of the breast (rapid onset, pathologic confirmation required).

Therefore a skin erythema/excoriation occupying >1/3rd suggests inflammatory carcinoma (T4d), not routine T4b. Ulceration, satellite nodules and peau d'orange are T4b features. (Options A, B, D are ruled out)

Key takeaways:

T4b = skin involvement (ulceration, nodules, localized peau d'orange).

T4d = inflammatory carcinoma (diffuse erythema/edema ≥1/3 breast).

References: AJCC/NCI staging summaries

questions.text: A patient with ureteric calculi is being investigated. What is the investigation of choice for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-contrast CT KUB (CT without contrast of kidney-ureter-bladder region) is the investigation of choice for suspected ureteric calculi because it has very high sensitivity and specificity for stone detection (detects radio-opaque and radiolucent stones), localizes stones accurately, and shows ancillary findings (hydronephrosis).

Ultrasound is useful in children/pregnancy or to screen but has lower sensitivity for mid/ distal ureteric stones. Contrast CT is not required for stone detection and can obscure calculi. Diagnostic ureteroscopy is an invasive test/intervention.

Explanation of other options:

USG KUB (Option A): operator-dependent and less sensitive (useful in pregnancy /paediatrics).

CECT (Option C): unnecessary; contrast can mask stones; used for other indications.

Ureteroscopy (Option D): therapeutic and invasive; not the diagnostic test of choice.

Key takeaways:

NCCT KUB = gold-standard initial imaging for adult suspected ureteric stone (except special populations).

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has fever, nausea and rebound tenderness with migration of pain to the right iliac fossa (RIF). Lab investigation shows raised TLC of 15,000. What is the Alvarado score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alvarado score components (MANTRELS mnemonic):

  • Migration of pain → 1 (present)
  • Anorexia → 1 (not mentioned → assume 0)
  • Nausea/vomiting → 1 (present)
  • Tenderness in RIF → 2 (explicitly not stated as "tenderness" in stem - the stem mentions rebound tenderness with migration to RIF; since rebound is explicitly stated but localized tenderness is not separately stated, the conservative exam interpretation used here is to score rebound = 1 but not assume the 2-point RLQ tenderness)
  • Rebound tenderness → 1 (present)
  • Elevated temperature → 1 (fever reported)
  • Leukocytosis (>10,000) → 2 (TLC 15,000)
  • Left shift → not mentioned → 0

Summing the clearly provided items without assuming an extra RLQ tenderness = 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 6.

Key takeaways:

Alvarado score ranges 0-10; ≥7 suggests probable appendicitis; 5-6 equivocal; ≤4 low probability.

questions.text: Which colloid is used in resuscitation as per the Muir & Barclay formula?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Muir & Barclay burn resuscitation protocol (widely used in some centres, especially historically in the UK) prescribes human albumin solution (4.5%) as the colloid component for the post-initial period.

The formula divides the first 36 hours into short epochs and prescribes colloid infusion (albumin) in addition to or instead of large crystalloid volumes. Modern practice varies (Parkland/crystalloid-based regimens are more common), but the Muir & Barclay regimen uses human albumin as the colloid.

Explanation of other options:

PRBC (Option A): blood products are reserved for anaemia/bleeding, not routine colloid in Muir-Barclay.

FFP (Option B): not the colloid used in that formula.

Dextran (Option D): historically used in colloid resuscitation in some settings, but the Muir & Barclay original/most-used regimen specifies albumin.

questions.text: Which is NOT correct about vacuum-assisted closure (VAC)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

VAC / NPWT (Negative Pressure Wound Therapy): well documented effects include reduced wound edema, improved perfusion and granulation tissue formation, and mechanical stimulation that promotes wound healing. The claim that VAC reduces bacterial load is controversial - some studies show reduced wound bioburden, others show no change or even increases; the effect on bacterial counts and infection rates is not uniformly proven. Thus the safest exam answer for "NOT correct" is the definitive statement "reduces bacterial load (Option A)". NPWT can be applied in continuous or intermittent modes (both used) and does promote granulation and reduce edema.

Key takeaways:

VAC/NPWT: good for difficult/large wounds, reduces edema and promotes granulation; effect on microbial load is inconsistent - use adjuncts where infection is suspected.

questions.text: Which of these is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Los Angeles (LA) classification grades reflux esophagitis (endoscopic mucosal breaks). Achalasia is classified by high-resolution manometry using the Chicago classification (types I-III). So LA classification does not apply to achalasia

Explanation of other options:

Chronic pancreatitis (Option A)- M-ANNHEIM: the M-ANNHEIM classification (pronounced "Mannheim") is an accepted classification and scoring system for chronic pancreatitis (etiology, stage, severity). So this pairing is essentially correct (note the common spelling M-ANNHEIM).

Colonoscopy - Boston score (Option C): the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale is used to grade bowel prep quality for colonoscopy.

Parathyroid resection - Miami criteria (Option D): the Miami intraoperative PTH criteria (drop of >50% from baseline at 10 min) guides adequacy of parathyroidectomy.

questions.text: Identify the bariatric surgery in the given image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SADI-S is a modification of the duodenal switch: a sleeve gastrectomy followed by a single duodeno-ileostomy creating a loop bypass; compared with classical DS it uses a single anastomosis. The radiographic/diagrammatic appearance (long gastric sleeve with single duodeno-ileal anastomosis) identifies SADI-S as distinct from simple sleeve or BPD with two anastomoses.


Explanation of other options:

Sleeve gastrectomy (Option A): only stomach resection without intestinal anastomosis.

BPD/DS (Option C&D): often involve more complex two-anastomosis reconstructions.

questions.text: Identify the procedure:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A dog-ear is the puckering/standing cone of tissue that can form at the end of an elliptic excision or closure. Dog-ear correction consists of removal/undermining of the cone and revision of wound edges to achieve a smooth contour. The provided image shows the classic postoperative revision of a small triangular puckered flap - consistent with dog-ear correction.

Explanation of other options:

I&D (Option A): would show drainage incision with pus.

STSG (Option B): would show graft harvest/placement over defect.

Keloid excision (Option C): larger raised scar excision; image more specific for dog-ear.

choices.text: Secure airway, needle thoracotomy, and IV fluids
Blood transfusion and send for CT
Take history, give IV Dextrose and send for eFAST
CT scan of head and airway securing

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma and breathlessness is found to have systolic BP 90 mmHg, SpO2 85%, GCS 8/15 and absent breath sounds. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is an unstable trauma patient (hypotension, hypoxia, depressed GCS) with absent breath sounds → highly suspicious for tension pneumothorax/large hemothorax. The primary survey (A-B-C) requires immediate airway management (GCS 8 → intubate) plus immediate decompression of the chest (needle thoracostomy or tube thoracostomy) before CT or further diagnostics. IV access and resuscitation follow. Waiting for CT or history in this unstable patient is inappropriate.

Explanation of other options:

Options B/C/D delay immediate life-saving interventions (decompression/airway) - unacceptable in unstable chest trauma.

questions.text: While cooking, a sudden cooker blast caused burns of face with singeing of eyebrows, bilateral upper limbs, and front of chest. What is the burn area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(A/c to Wallace Rule of Nines in adult):

  • Head & neck (anterior + posterior) = 9% total. If only face is burned (anterior head), that's roughly 5%; singeing of eyebrows suggests anterior head/face involvement (we will count 4.5%).
  • Bilateral upper limbs = 9% each = 18% total.
  • Anterior chest = 9%. (Anterior chest and abdomen is 9% each; thus anterior torso as whole is 18%)

Sum (face 4.5 + both arms 18 + anterior chest 9) ≈ 31.5% → thus 27-30%.

Key takeaways:

In adults: head & neck = 9%, each arm = 9%, anterior chest = 9%; adjust if only partial head/face is involved.

  • Use Lund-Browder chart for children/precise assessment.

questions.text: The mammogram and histopathological picture of a woman with breast cancer is given below. She had undergone a mastectomy. Her aunt died of cancer. Which test will you do for the sister of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A family history of breast cancer (first/second-degree relatives) raises suspicion for hereditary breast/ovarian cancer syndromes. The mammogram shows Spiculated, irregular, high-density mass in the breast. While the histopath specimen shows Tumour cells forming irregular nests and cords and Fibrous stroma reaction (desmoplasia). This is indicative of Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC), the most common breast cancer (75-80%). It is most commonly associated with BRCA1 mutation.

BRCA1/BRCA2 germline testing is indicated in families with breast cancer, especially with affected relatives or early onset disease.

Explanation of other options:

TP53 (Option B) (Li-Fraumeni) can also predispose to breast cancer but is less commonly the first targeted gene;

CDH1 (Option C) is linked to hereditary diffuse gastric cancer with lobular breast cancer;

RET (Option D) pertains to MEN2 (medullary thyroid carcinoma) and not primary breast cancer screening.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Histopathology reveals that the tumor has invaded the muscularis propria but there is no involvement of lymph nodes or distant metastasis. According to the Dukes staging system, what is the most appropriate stage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this scenario, a tumour invading muscularis propria but does not penetrate it and with no involvement of lymph nodes or distant metastasis, Points to Dukes stage B1 (Stage IIa).

Explanation of other options:

Stage 0 (Option A): carcinoma in situ (no muscular invasion).

Dukes A (Option B): limited to mucosa/submucosa.

Dukes B2 (Option D): through muscularis into serosa / perirectal tissues.
